pain.3: Daily, limiting most activities or requiring analgesics

varicose_veins.2: Multiple GSV varicosities confined to calf or thigh
varicose_veins.3: Extensive, involving calf and thigh or GSV and SSV

edema.2: Extends above ankle but below knee

pigmentation.2: Diffuse over lower third of calf
pigmentation.3: Wider distribution above lower third of calf

inflammation.2: Diffuse over lower third of calf
inflammation.3: Wider distribution above lower third of calf

induration.2: Diffuse over lower third of calf
induration.3: Wider distribution above lower third of calf

presentation: Pain ranging from occasional to severe limiting activities
Edema from ankle to above knee
Skin changes including pigmentation, inflammation, induration
Active ulcers of varying number, duration, and size
diagnosis: Combine with CEAP for complete documentation
treatment: Track VCSS before and after intervention
Target ≥4 point improvement as clinically significant
Use for quality benchmarking and outcome reporting
Combine with QOL measures for comprehensive assessment

definition.@value: A validated clinical instrument for quantifying the severity of chronic venous disease across 10 clinical domains, each scored 0-3, enabling outcome measurement and treatment monitoring.

sources.source: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed. McGraw-Hill.

learning_objectives: Apply VCSS scoring to patients with chronic venous disease
Distinguish VCSS from CEAP in clinical use
clinical_pearls: VCSS is for outcome measurement; CEAP is for classification
A change of ≥4 points is clinically significant
Ulcer components (3 items) can contribute 9 points maximum
Maximum possible score is 30; typical severe CVD scores 15-20
